### **Accessibility & Layout Notes**

- **Font & Contrast:** Use a sans‑serif font (e.g., Arial or Open Sans, 12 pt or larger) and a high‑contrast text/background combination (minimum 4.5 : 1).  
- **Headings:** Mark each section with proper HTML heading tags (`<h1>–<h3>`) or clear style levels in a PDF for screen‑reader navigation.  
- **Alt Text:** Provide brief, descriptive alt‑text for any icons or visuals (“leaf decorative icon” or “check‑mark icon”).  
- **Expandable Sections:** For web versions, `<details>` elements should include a `<summary>` label in plain language and open/close smoothly via keyboard.  
- **Table Formatting:** When using tables, specify column headers so assistive technology can read them correctly.  
- **Color Use:** Don’t rely on color alone to convey meaning; pair color cues with symbols or text.  
- **Hyperlinks:** Write the full target name (“findahelpline.com – international crisis lines”) rather than bare URLs, so users understand where a link leads.
